Blah. Missed last week's topic. Oh well :-(

I was gonna be gone all week, but turns out I have minimal email. Might as
well reply:
> I was hoping somebody would mention triggers.
>
> Well, if we had triggers, I'd redo my "Tunneled Labyrinth" to make a
> trigger where as soon as the last opponent was killed, all the walls
> would come down.
>
> Also, if we had triggers, I'd redo my "Castle Defenses" to make a
> trigger where once the 4 towers were destroyed, the NPC would increase
> its experience level.

Triggers (simple ones) might not be too hard to implement.. I'll look into
it when the port is finished. There's already a "NPC Must Survive" option,
so that's some sort of minimal trigger. Might be interesting to expand on
that.
>
> Of course, if we had triggers and a 3-d map, I would make all my ocean
> going scenarios one map where you have to do things in order.
>
> Of course, I have an even better than idea than triggers: Handicapped
> Scenarios.
>
> That would be a scenario where from 1 to 4 different magical attacks
> are disabled.
>
> One combo of 4 that I would like to have disabled is freeze time,
> chain-lightning, mind control, and charm opponent for certain
> scenarios.
>
> Another combo of attacks I would like to disable for certain scenarios
> is teleport and tunnel.

How special abilities are implemented right now, that shouldn't be too
hard to do either. Just a matter of adding more stuff to scen files and
adding checks in that 1.5k-line function for special attacks.

Other things that might make scenarios better:

In-game level-ups (this can kinda go under triggers). For example, if you
have an arena map that can be played for a long time (lots of drumstics),
and your chars level up in-game, it creates for a much more interesting
long-term level.
Character respawn: also useful for arena maps, and just nice overall when
wanted.
- Zardus
